Hi,

If I begin writing this GUI (I will, but my job is taking a lot of my =

time right now), it will be mostly 3D and targeted for the Win32 
platform=
. The node placement schemes can be implemented in a similar 
way as vector=
 graphics is. Ken, I will do some study on these 
algorithms. 

I already h=
ave a substrate class, capable of generating a parralel 
(layered, like mos=
t drawings of backprop nets), circular and a matrix-
like layers of nodes i=
n 3D, given the node counts for each layer. 
I'll add spherical, cubic and =
perhaps even random such schemes. 

I like the idea of taking apart the sub=
strate from the CPPN-NEAT 
stuff. They are no similar things at all. It suc=
ks to have your 
experimental application generate the substrate in some al=
gorithmic 
way. 
There should be a stand-alone app that deals with substrat=
es, and 
another one that runs the evolution and is experiment-specific. Th=
is 
is more flexible. 

I am currently running experiments with leaky-integ=
rator networks, 
the CPPNs have 3 outputs and when the biases and time cons=
tants are 
computed, the (x1, y1, 1.0) are used only (others are set to 0.0=
). 
This was a suggestion that Ken told me, and I want to thank him for 
th=
is, because I see this is the right way to evolve node properties 
along wi=
th connections with the same connective CPPN :) 

So the GUI I am planning =
will possibly include CTRNN substrates as 
well. 

As soon as I have it wor=
king, I will send the application & source in 
the files section. I appreci=
ate any help with this from our 
community. 

Peter

> Ken and Petar,

> If I unde=
rstand correctly what you are trying to accomplish, you 
might want
> to lo=
ok a force-directed graph placement algorithm for node 
placement given
> c=
onnection nodes. Examples are Fruchterman-Reingold, Eades, Kamada-
Kawai,
>=
 Hadany-Harel.  Personally, I use Gajer-Kobourov GRIP (Graph dRawing 
with
=
> Intelligent Placement).  There have been great strides in reducing 
the t=
ime
> complexity in these algorithms, and these may be expanded (with 
litt=
le
> adaptation) to n-dimensional cubes (and with a little more effort 
sep=
arable
> n-dim Hilbert spaces, or Riemann spaces).
>  
> Genome graphs may =
be then be presented in a GUI in OpenGL or 
DirectX.  The
> actual arithmet=
ic computations for simulations can also be off-
loaded to the
> GPU (as I =
have alluded to earlier).
>  
> A simple virtual quaternion trackball may b=
e used to manipulate the 
view.
>  
> Ken
